items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely from 10:30am, Sunday 7 November, over the next few hours and into this evening. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boatyards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am, Monday 8 November 2021.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: This flood alert has been removed due to improving weather conditions and falling tides. Please continue to be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
As a result of Forecast high spring tides will raise water levels in the harbour. This is expected to result in standing water affecting footpaths and low lying land on the seaward side of flood defences.  Forecast high water is 10:45 on 07/11/21 with a level of 1.24 mAOD and a Force 3 West wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and properties is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon   
The maximum forecast tidal height is 1.24m AOD.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 07/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This flood alert has been removed due to improving weather conditions and falling tides. Please continue to be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. We will continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 15:30 on 06/11/21 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 48 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 07/11/21, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:15pm and 2:15pm this afternoon, Sunday 7 November 2021. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.32 mAODN at 1:15pm, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.61m above tide tables, wind Force 6, NorthWesterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Sunday 7 November 2021.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary today, Sunday 7th November between 05:30 and 09:30 hours. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated later on Sunday 7th November 2021.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary today, Sunday 7th November between 05:30 and 09:30 hours. items.description: North Sea coast at Hornsea

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: Spring tides and strong winds are forecast to bring high levels and large waves along the Yorkshire coast on Sunday 7th November. The area most at risk are properties from Marine Drive, along South Promenade, Hornsea Burton Road and along Stream Dike and Foss Beck. Some of the highest tides of the year are expected over this weekend, and the forecast shows that, due to the local weather conditions, Sunday evening’s tide will be particularly high. The highest levels are expected on Sunday evening, between 17:30-19:45. Our operational staff will be out inspecting our flood defences before and after the peak tides, and we are liaising closely with our partners. Please keep away from flood water. To report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline number 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings. Keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline number 0345 988 1188. This message will be updated later on Sunday 7th November 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast today, Sunday 7th November between 17:30 and 19:45 hours. The particular areas at risk are exposed frontages and paths around Hornsea. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated later on Sunday 7th November 2021 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to continue to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds at Newbiggin Bay, Beadnell Harbour Road North. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 15:30 PM and 18:30 PM this afternoon, 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 to 4 hours either side of this time. Our incident duty staff are monitoring the situation. We do not expect to issue any Flood Warnings at this time.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 PM Sunday 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: High water levels are forecast this evening as a result of spring tides and strong winds. Forecast high water is 20:30 on 7/11/21 with a level of 6.30 mAOD and a Force 4 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland may be possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease, and tidal levels fall, for the 8/11/21 high tide at 08:45. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 8/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual. Tides will be at their highest at 19:30 this evening, 07/11/21. Flooding to properties/roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  

Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or if the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:15pm and 2:15pm this afternoon, Sunday 7 November 2021. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 3.03 mAODN at 1:15pm, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.72m above tide tables, wind Force 6, NorthWesterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables).  You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Sunday 7 November 2021.

(mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood alert has been issued due to a high tide forecast for Sunday afternoon, 07/11/2021.  Highest tide is expected to be at 13:45 this afternoon. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time from 11:45 to 15:45. Flooding to properties is not expected.
Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures and are prepared to respond if required.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. For those who need it, the forecast total water height at Sheerness for the 13:45 Sunday afternoon tide is 3.54mAOD.
This message will be updated this evening, 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest throughout the afternoon at 12:30 PM on 07/11/2021.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 12:30 PM on 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 02:30 PM on 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 12:30 pm on 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.
This tide is the last of this high spring tidal cycle.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated within 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tidal levels are expected to overtop sea defences.  Forecast high water is at 21:00 on 07/11/21 with a level of 7.45 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.   Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide at 09:15 on 08/11/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 08/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. Subsequent tides have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on 07/11/2021. Levels around Arpley may still remain high until midday today 07/11/2021, but are expected to be just below the flood alert threshold. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the alert if necessary.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
Wye Estuary at Brockweir
Tidal flooding of areas near the Wash Frontage in Lincolnshire
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday afternoon. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the Wash Frontage. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:15 on 7th November 2021, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Yorkshire Coast today, Sunday 7th November between 17:15 and 18:30 hours. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Staithes and Whitby, alongside low lying paths around Whitby Harbour. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated later on Sunday 7th November 2021 or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 5:15am and 9:15am Sunday 7th November. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.81mAODN at 7:15am, on Sunday 7th of November, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is likely the alert may be re-issued for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the bottom third of Langstone High Street, although flood depths in the road will be relatively shallow. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 07/11/2021.

(mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is possible we may need to re-issue this Alert for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 1pm tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday afternoon. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the South Humber Bank between Whitton and South Ferriby. The time and date of the forecast high water is 19:00 on 7th November 2021, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first. Our forecasts currently indicate that the closure of the A1077 flood gate isn't required and flooding to properties is not expected. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 8:00am and midday on Sunday 7th November. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 2.07mAODN at 10:00am, on Sunday 7th of November, which is 0.83m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly, which will be blowing strongly offshore. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.message: This flood alert is being removed as, due to offshore winds overnight, this morning’s tide was not as high as expected.  Another high spring tide, currently forecast to be a little lower than this morning’s one, is expected this evening between 8:30 to 10:30 pm. Tidal levels will be falling going into next week. Following this morning’s high tide, our operational staff are checking our flood embankments and other defences in the area. Please keep away from flood water and to report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline 0345 988 1188.

items.message:
This flood alert remains in force due to the possibility of minor impacts from tidal and coastal flooding on Sunday 7th November. Due to offshore winds overnight, this morning’s tide was not as high as expected.  Another high spring tide, currently forecast to be a little lower, or a similar height to this morning’s one, is expected this evening between 8:30 to 9:30 pm. Following this morning’s high tide, our operational staff are checking our flood embankments and other defences in the area. We anticipate removing this flood alert on Monday morning, as tidal levels fall going into next week. 
Please keep away from flood water and to report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline 0345 988 1188. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 8am tomorrow morning, Sunday 7 November, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth tomorrow will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  It is likely that we may need to re-issue the flood alert for Sunday evening's tide. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7 November.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 8am tomorrow morning, Sunday 7th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth tomorrow will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  It is likely that we may need to re-issue the flood alert for Sunday evening's tide. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  This message will be updated by 4pm tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: Selsey Bill to Elmer
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide is 6.41 metres Chart Datum (3.36 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, Mill Lane, Sidlesham will flood, making access temporarily more difficult. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. Avoid driving on Mill Lane, Sidlesham at high tide, flood water can contain hidden dangers. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide is 6.41 metres Chart Datum (3.36 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide will cause flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk. Water will be high up slipways and could be forced up through drains causing minor flooding to roads. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide, in Littlehampton Rope Walk. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide is 6.41 metres Chart Datum (3.36 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, a small amount of water may pond on nearby land, fields and at Climping Street Car Park. If the waves are a little larger than currently forecast, a small amount of water may then flow westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards residential property in Climping Street. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. We have recycled shingle at Climping in advance of this weekend. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Thorney Island to Bracklesham
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.19 m. The total forecast tide is 5.25 metres Chart Datum (2.51 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide might flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge.  Flooding is possible on high tides at approximately 08:15, tomorrow morning, 07/11/21 at Keadby. Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road.

We expect river levels to remain high until after the high tide at 09:00 on 07/11/21 at Keadby.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: High water levels are forecast to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown tomorrow lunchtime, Sunday 07/11/2021, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 12:00 and 12:30 tomorrow, 07/11/2021, with high tide at 12:15. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea and low lying land along the tidal Stour. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and our partners and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.37m AOD and the total water level will be 3.91m AOD.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because our latest forecast shows possible flooding to coastal roads, footpaths and businesses at the Harbour between 08:15am and 12:15pm on Sunday 7th November. Areas most at risk are around Southwold Harbour, Ferry road, the bottom of Queens Road and Constitution Hill, North Road, the bottom of Pier Avenue and Mights Road in Southwold and Bridge Road and Hillside Road in Reydon. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.15mAODN at 10:15am, on Sunday 7th November, which is 0.87m above tide tables, wind Force 7, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). High water at Southwold will be around 1 hour later.  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 1pm tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Dartford Creek and The Mardyke to the Thames Barrier
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Newham, Thurrock

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a closure of the Thames Barrier.

Water will be maintained within the downstream network of flood defences, which include river walls, embankments and flood gates, however flooding of low lying footpaths and open spaces is possible for 1-2 hours around high tide.

The forecast high tide at the Thames Barrier is at 14:30 on 07/11/21.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground ensuring all flood gates are closed.

Members of the public are advised to avoid floodwater and also to keep abreast of updates to the forecast as further Thames Barrier closures are possible.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 08/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely from 10:30am Sunday 7 November, over the next few hours and into this evening. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9pm Sunday 7 November 2021.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton, to and including, Lee-over-Sands
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 12:15pm and 2:15pm this afternoon, Sunday 7 November 2021. Areas most at risk are the Golf Course and roads around the Martello Towers in Clacton, as well as Jaywick, Sea Wick, Lee over Sands and holiday parks in those areas. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.32 mAODN at 1:15pm, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.61m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Sunday 7 November 2021.

items.description: The Essex coast from Leigh on Sea, to and including, Hadleigh Marshes, and Two Tree Island

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.83mAODN at 1:45pm, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.49m above tide tables, wind Force 5, north westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm today Sunday 7 November 2021.

items.description: The Essex coast at West Mersea, including The Strood and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely between 12:15pm and 2:15pm today, Sunday 7 November 2021. Areas most at risk are marshland around Mersea Island, The Strood, waterside properties in West Mersea, including those on Shears Crescent, Coast Road, Seaview holiday park and Waldegraves holiday park. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.32 mAODN at 1:15pm, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.61m above tide tables, wind Force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Sunday 7 November 2021.
